captions.text:
Eons before the Age of Ancients, there was
only Dark. Within the dark the world was unformed,

until it wasn't. Dust, rock and fog shaped.
Within the fog everlasting dragons, grey crags,

and arch trees reside in a state of perpetual
tranquility; free of storm. But, all of that

is about to change. Below the surface a fiery
core was discovered by creatures that came

out of the dark. The core was the first flame.
The flame brought about many changes; it brought

Life, death, and of course light and dark.
The creatures from the Dark obtained these

fundamental elements of life, death, light
and dark from within the flame. They deemed

them Lord's Souls.
The captures of these Lord's Souls would become

personifications of the elements they begot.
First was Nito, the capture of and personification

of death. Soon to follow was the Witch, the
mother who borne children and manifest life.

Gwyn would seize the light, so gloriously
incandescent. And the final Lord's Soul, was

Dark -- hidden and forgotten.
With their newfound power the Lords challenged

the dragons on the surface. Gwyn hurled bolts
of sunlight; peeling away the dragon's immortal

skin. Nito diseased their exposed flesh, leaving
them decayed. And the witches burnt their

sanctuaries, the arch trees.
In the end, the Lords were victorious over

the Everlasting Dragons. But at great cost.
The dragons shall never be forgotten...

We knights fought valiantly, but for every
one of them, we lost three score of our own.

With devastating loses The Age of Ancients
was no more. A new age was upon the world;

the Age of Fire; the Age of Gwyn.
After the War of Ancients, the Dragons were

driven nearly into extinction by Gwyn and
his faithful knights. With the dragons removed

from the surface the Lords were given opportunity
to flourish and for a time the Age of Fire

was prosperous. During this time Gwyn had
three children; an unknown firstborn son,

a daughter Gwynevere and a frail boy Gwyndolin.
Additionally, great cities and civilizations

were formed. With culture came covenants to
worship and pay homage to these great deities,

and many humans took the Lords as their Gods;
none more-so than Gwyn, the Lord of Sunlight.

But, Gwyn himself either loathed humanity
or feared it all the same, made evident by

those closest to the Lord of Sunlight and
their attitude toward humans.

Halt!
This is the tomb of the Great Lord Gwyn.

Tarnished, it shall not be, by the feet of
men.

You humans...
...always taking what you please, always resorting

to force.
Humans... mmmhhh, what vile creatures

Thou are strong, human. Surely thine kind
are more than pure dark

Gwyn's disdain for humans was rooted in a
fear of the Dark Soul; the counterbalance

to his power. The first human, the pygmy who
found the Dark Soul, split the lightless Lords

soul into countless shards, bequeathing the
fragments to humans; giving them their humanity.

The Lord of Sunlight found though, that if
humanity was sacrificed to the First Flame

through the Fire Link, the destruction of
Dark Soul fragments brightened the light;

fueling the flame and igniting his power.
Humans and the undead they produced would

be tolerated, but nothing more, if only to
prolong the Age of Fire and prosperity.

But where humans thrive in great concentration,
darkness seems to accumulate as well; little

by little inching forward, consuming the light.
As humans became more prosperous the First

Flame began to fade. In fear of the dark and
the dwindling First Flame, Gwyn seeks the

Witch of Izalith for aid once again. At Gwyn's
behest, the Witch of Izalith attempts to use

the power of her Lord's Soul in combination
with pyromancy magic to duplicate the First

Flame, but the powerful spell is corrupted
and births life to all demons instead.

Gwyn is now confronted with a new threat of
chaotic demons in addition to the darkness.

War on all fronts is spreading Gwyn's influence
and power thin. During the Great Demon War,

an unknown primordial serpent approaches the
sorcerers of Oolacile; pleading with them

to upturn the grave of Primeval Man, either
to deliver the final blow, ending the Age

of Fire while it's weak or to scavenge what
remains of the Dark Lord's Soul to satiate

the First Flame's hunger. Yet, neither goal
is met as the Primeval Man fathered a light-devouring

Abyss and his rage infects humans, mutating
their humanity; turning them into feral creatures.

In fear of the Abyss, Gwyn sends three of
his greatest warriors to deal with the darkness

of Oolacile. Although the great knight Artorias
was able to slay the Father of the Abyss,

none of the knights return from Oolacile;
a devastating blow to Gwyn's strength. After

the fall of Oolacile, Gwyn orders the great
human city New Londo to be purged, for there

are creatures there known to serve the dark
even before the abyss was found in the city's

depths. At too great a risk to the Age of
Fire, New Londo is flooded, murdering many

humans.
The Lord of Sunlight is not unfamiliar with

genocide; he destroyed all the dragons to
usher the Age of Fire into prominence, if

the humans must die as well, then so be it.
The Lord of Sunlight will make any sacrifice

to insure the Age of Fire, but the massacre
has unforeseen consequence.

Recognizing the dire situation many of the
Gods of Anor Londo abandoned Lordran and with

many of Gwyn's allies perished or lost, the
Age of Fire falls into a state of entropy;

decaying into obscurity.
There is only one course of action that remains,

Gwyn will sacrifice himself to the Fire Link.
Before departing he speaks with youngest son,

Gwyndolin the last remaining deity of Anor
Londo, ordering him to shepherd the humans

to the North, away from Lordran, away from
the Flame.

Gwyn is the Lord of Sunlight, but all suns
must set; and in that twilight -- the period

when day is ending and night is beginning
-- is what Gwyn fears the most; a time when

only dark will remain. With no other avenue
to pursue, Gwyn ventures across the Ash Dunes

of the kiln into the heart of the Fire Link
to reignite the dwindling Age of Fire.

...Thou will understand, one day.
At thy twilight, old thoughts return, in great

waves of nostalgia.
Gywn reaches forth with an absolute sense

of clarity; completely lucid of his willingness
to sacrifice any life to prolong the Age of

Fire. As he touches the Fire Link, as the
flame begins to consume the Soul it once offered,

in a moment too late with no return, Gwyn
realizes what he truly sacrificed: Love, his

children, his integrity; everything he should
have cherished... gone.

Now he only remains as a hollow; a husk. The
Lord of Cinder, like the mindless undead;

devoid of humanity.
If only Gwyn had not resented humanity, he

could have learned much from them: their willingness
to sacrifice anything for the ones they love,

their unrelenting hope for the future, even
when the universe has none to offer in return,

their magnificent strength and willpower to
topple obstacles larger than themselves, their

hunger for knowledge and pursuit of the ultimate
truths, their ability to be knocked down,

time and again only to stand up and fight
once more.

Dark is not the end. Humanity is just the
beginning. There is a balance to all things

and just as it started, so shall it finish
in dark. For one era's end is another's Genesis.

title: Dark Souls Lore: Gwyn The Lord of Sunlight

comments.text:
+dasg hagery We don't know it was the Humanity Phantoms that broke his arm, 
for one.  More people than not tend to assume that it was Manus who did it, 
which would explain how Sif was able to place a summon sign in his boss 
arena.  But even if we were to discount that likelihood, multiple item 
descriptions related to humanity and dark magic describe them as having 
great physical texture and impact, which is why dark sorceries do so much 
poise/stability damage.  And Artorias, being inhuman and thus ignorant to 
the nature of humanity, wouldn't automatically know not to try to block the 
Humanity Phantoms, or that the sorceries of Manus or the Bloatheads 
dwelling in the Chasm of the Abyss would hit incredibly hard.  All of which 
renders it immensely more likely that his broken left arm was being used to 
wield his shield rather than his sword.

As for Sif and Artorias's shared attacks, saying that "any dog with a sword 
could spin" rather fervently ignores the fact that dogs don't naturally 
know how to use a sword in the first place.  All of Sif's combat prowess 
displayed in his boss fight was taught to him directly by Artorias, making 
their shared spin move still relevant.  All of which ignores the fact that 
you are incorrect in claiming that they only share that one move.  They 
also both swing their swords in wide arcs in the process of leaping a huge 
distance backward with identical timing to boot, and there are tons of less 
direct analogues between their strategies (slamming their swords straight 
down on top of the player either in isolation or at the end of a combo, a 
sudden dash forward combined with a powerful sword strike, jumping long 
distances away periodically so as to not let the player get too large of a 
window to deal damage to them and calmly pacing forward to conserve energy 
in the meantime, and so on).  It would truthfully be hugely more difficult 
to compose a list of the ways their fighting styles differ than it would to 
show how alike they are.  Which means that Artorias was indeed fighting 
very much the way he would under normal circumstances, a feat that would be 
unthinkable if he wasn't wielding his sword in the proper hand.

comments.text:
+Esteran Art and LP Solaire calls the sun a "magnificent father," which is 
odd, but not that out of the ordinary at the beginning. He talks about his 
obsession with the sun, and he admits that it sounds a little crazy. The 
game even goes out of its way to point out that the symbols on Solaire's 
clothing and shield are drawn there himself - it wants the player to know 
that this is not something common for knights of Astora - it's very 
[i]specifically[/i] an obsession of this one guy. If you talk to Patches 
about Solaire, Patches pretty much flat out says that Solaire is harmless 
but crazy. Patches also makes pretty accurate assessments of both Lautrec 
and Petrus, so I think it's pretty fair to say that Solaire comes across 
that way not just to the player, but to other people. The fact that Solaire 
is in agreement with this tells me that not even he fully understands why 
the sun is so important to him. That, and there's the way he dies - a 
Sunlight Maggot. Solaire essentially dies by "giving up" - he's at one his 
lowest points in his journey, both literally and figuratively, and it's 
here that he sees something producing light similar to the sun. His final 
transition to complacency is what ultimately drives him hollow. 

This implies to me a couple things:

1. Solaire knows of his lineage and circumstances only subconsciously, and 
it's his soul (actually that of a god) that was incarnated into a human 
body (Perhaps intentionally on the part of his superiors). He 
subconsciously sees the sun as a literal father and wants to be like it in 
the same way the first born might have wanted to be like his father.

2. Solaire's quest really is to be like the sun, not just heed the call of 
the undead to ring the bells and what not. If he gives up after literally 
becoming like a lame sun through the Sunlight Maggot, I think it might be 
that he is being driven to do this by the influence of his soul - which 
might be seeking redemption. In this sense it reminds me a lot of classical 
heroes who are unaware of their deific roots, like Ram in the 
[i]Ramayan[/i] or Hercules who also happens to be seeking redemption in his 
story. 

So now there's Gwyn's first-born. We know that no one knows his name, that 
people still try to worship him (the broken statue of him at the Altar of 
Sunlight that still has followers praying near it implies to me that this 
was an intentional act of censorship by the gods, and not an organic 
process of people simply forgetting his name), and that he screwed up 
somehow in a way that led to a major military defeat in the time following 
Gwyn's self-sacrifice. Also that he cared "only for power." We know that he 
leaves his ring on Gwyn's tomb as a "final farewell," perhaps showing some 
kind of regret for ultimately being a disappointment and failing to become 
like his father

Then there are the minor points. Solare becomes a Warrior of Sunlight, 
calls the sun a "magnificent father," and has weapons and clothes that 
don't have any particular power. Now remember that most bosses have weapons 
that do something pretty special - Quelaag's a Daughter of Chaos and 
obviously can produce her own fire, but still wields a sword that generates 
flames. Nito uses the Gravelord's Sword which also has its own benefits. 
Ornstein's corpse gives Smough lightning powers so we know he has some of 
that in him, but his spear also shoots lightning. Who's the only boss/god 
that wields a weapon that overtly exhibits extraordinary powers in his boss 
fight, but does nothing when you get it? That's right, Gwyn. Now to be 
fair, Gwyn's given away all of his power to his children and himself to the 
fire when you fight him, and that might mean that his weapon doesn't have 
fire in it because it's the flame granting that to Gwyn temporarily. Yet, 
it seems like he would have infused lightning into his weapon like every 
other person seems to do with their special powers and equipment long 
before giving up his lightning. Note that the first born son used Sunlight 
Blade, which would be applied to a mundane weapon. Anyway, I think that 
going out of the way to point out that there is absolutely nothing special 
about Solaire's equipment could imply that there's more to him than meets 
the eye. It could, of course, also be interpreted literally - that he's 
just the hardest-working, most dedicated hero.

So basically, I think Gwyn's first-born son may have become a human after 
having his status as a deity forcefully taken from him, and he lost his 
memory. The result is a human seeking to become "like the sun" because he's 
actually living out the redemptive desires of the person he was in his past 
life.

- He's the only NPC in the game that throws lightning bolts like Gwyn could.

- Even though he was hurling lightning bolts, his talisman is simply a 
normal one that he drew a sun on. :P 

- It's said that the former "God of War" still watches over his fellow 
warriors (sunlight medal description): Solaire repeatedly shows up in your 
game and can be summoned to fight alongside you for boss battles. 

- He seems to know entirely too much about how the distorted flow of time 
works in Lordran for someone who just became undead and went looking for 
his "own sun". 

- In his dialogue, it seems as though he somehow willingly "chose" to 
become Undead to go to Lordran. Everyone else seems to have been stuck with 
the ill-fortune of being cursed somehow, but Solaire makes it sound as if 
he willingly acquired it.

comments.text:
In the Light we see clearly all the world has to offer, both benevolent and 
malevolent. In the Dark the world is obscured, we see nothing and fear what 
we cannot see or understand in the wreathing black.

But what Gwyn did not foresee, was that the beginning of the Dark is not 
the end of the Light.

For in the night sky that is the antithesis of his day sky there are pock 
marks of light breaching the all consuming blackness.

For in that sky is the brilliant moon basking the world in a gentle glow.

And in the peak of the Dark's time, sight is cut off, and nothing but the 
sounds of unknown creatures, and the cold can be sensed. A Light, grand and 
brilliant cleaves through the Darkened sky and shadowed land on the 
horizon. The Sun returns to end the Midnight and a new Day is born.

Like the ceaseless cycle of Night and Day, the Primeval Flame must wane and 
sleep so the Dark can have it's age. And when the kindling is placed, and 
the fuel is chosen, the Primeval Flame will roar back to brilliance and 
banish the Dark again and again in the cycle of life, death, and rebirth.﻿

comments.text:
When I was about to fight Gwyn, and I entered the mist, only to be greeted 
by a husk holding a blazing sword, without even a cutscene, and with a 
melancholic song in the background. The song touched deep into my psyche, 
and left me with tears in my eyes, as I watched the soulless hollow that 
Gwyn had become. In the same way I fought him to link the first flame, I 
fought him to put him out of his misery, to let him rest in peace after all 
that had transpired. When after trading many blows, my Bastard Sword met 
his neck diagonally and cut clean through his torso, I could have sworn I 
heard him whisper: "Finally, it's over..."; I sat for a moment, and admired 
the first flame. The sparkle of life that fed every living being up until 
now. So close, yet, so far. So mighty, yet, so fragile. Is this what is 
necessary for the humans to keep living? When my flame dies out, who will 
be next, and for how long? This place isn't what one would expect from the 
once powerful Lord of Sunlight. No. His flame has died out, and mine will 
one day, if I am to feed the flame with myself. No. I am not letting this 
happen. I will make these stray children rise, even if they are to be 
raised in the dark. I stand up, and slowly turn away from the flame... I 
walk out of the kiln, not knowing what to expect in the way out, but sure 
of what to do no matter what happens...﻿
